text: After Ahab died, Moab rebelled against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah fell through a window lattice in his upper chamber in Samaria and was injured. He sent messengers with these orders, “Go, ask Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron, if I will survive this injury.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord told Elijah the Tishbite, “Get up; go to meet the messengers from the king of Samaria. Say this to them: ‘You must think there is no God in Israel! That explains why you are on your way to seek an oracle from Baal Zebub the god of Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore this is what the Lord has said, “You will not leave the bed you lie on, for you will certainly die!”’” So Elijah went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers returned to the king, he asked them, “Why have you returned?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “A man came up to meet us. He told us, ‘Go back to the king who sent you and tell him, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘You must think there is no God in Israel! That explains why you are sending for an oracle from Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron. Therefore you will not leave the bed you lie on, for you will certainly die.’”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king asked them, “Describe the appearance of this man who came up to meet you and told you these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “He was a hairy man and had a leather belt tied around his waist.” The king said, “He is Elijah the Tishbite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent a captain and his fifty soldiers to retrieve Elijah. The captain went up to him while he was sitting on the top of a hill. He told him, “Prophet, the king says, ‘Come down!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah replied to the captain, “If I am indeed a prophet, may fire come down from the sky and consume you and your fifty soldiers!” Fire then came down from the sky and consumed him and his fifty soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent another captain and his fifty soldiers to retrieve Elijah. He went up and told him, “Prophet, this is what the king says, ‘Come down at once!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah replied to them, “If I am indeed a prophet, may fire come down from the sky and consume you and your fifty soldiers!” Fire from God came down from the sky and consumed him and his fifty soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent a third captain and his fifty soldiers. This third captain went up and fell on his knees before Elijah. He begged for mercy, “Prophet, please have respect for my life and for the lives of these fifty servants of yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, fire came down from the sky and consumed the two captains who came before me, along with their men. So now, please have respect for my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Elijah, “Go down with him. Don’t be afraid of him.” So he got up and went down with him to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to the king, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘You sent messengers to seek an oracle from Baal Zebub, the god of Ekron. Is it because there is no God in Israel from whom you can seek a message? Therefore you will not leave the bed you lie on, for you will certainly die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did die in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through Elijah. In the second year of the reign of King Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat over Judah, Ahaziah’s brother Jehoram replaced him as king of Israel, because he had no son.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Ahaziah’s reign, including his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just before the Lord took Elijah up to heaven in a windstorm, Elijah and Elisha were traveling from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah told Elisha, “Stay here, for the Lord has sent me to Bethel.” But Elisha said, “As certainly as the Lord lives and as you live, I will not leave you.” So they went down to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some members of the prophetic guild in Bethel came out to Elisha and said, “Do you know that today the Lord is going to take your master from you?” He answered, “Yes, I know. Be quiet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to him, “Elisha, stay here, for the Lord has sent me to Jericho.” But he replied, “As certainly as the Lord lives and as you live, I will not leave you.” So they went to Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some members of the prophetic guild in Jericho approached Elisha and said, “Do you know that today the Lord is going to take your master from you?” He answered, “Yes, I know. Be quiet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to him, “Stay here, for the Lord has sent me to the Jordan.” But he replied, “As certainly as the Lord lives and as you live, I will not leave you.” So they traveled on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifty members of the prophetic guild went and stood opposite them at a distance, while Elijah and Elisha stood by the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took his cloak, folded it up, and hit the water with it. The water divided, and the two of them crossed over on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had crossed over, Elijah said to Elisha, “What can I do for you, before I am taken away from you?” Elisha answered, “May I receive a double portion of the prophetic spirit that energizes you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah replied, “That’s a difficult request! If you see me taken from you, may it be so, but if you don’t, it will not happen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were walking along and talking, suddenly a fiery chariot pulled by fiery horses appeared. They went between Elijah and Elisha, and Elijah went up to heaven in a windstorm.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Elisha was watching, he was crying out, “My father, my father! The chariot and horsemen of Israel!” Then he could no longer see him. He grabbed his clothes and tore them in two.
speaker: Narrator

text: He picked up Elijah’s cloak, which had fallen off him, and went back and stood on the shore of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the cloak that had fallen off Elijah, hit the water with it, and said, “Where is the Lord, the God of Elijah?” When he hit the water, it divided and Elisha crossed over.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the members of the prophetic guild in Jericho, who were standing at a distance, saw him do this, they said, “The spirit that energized Elijah rests upon Elisha.” They went to meet him and bowed down to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Look, there are fifty capable men with your servants. Let them go and look for your master, for the wind sent from the Lord may have carried him away and dropped him on one of the hills or in one of the valleys.” But Elisha replied, “Don’t send them out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were so insistent that he became embarrassed. So he said, “Send them out.” They sent the fifty men out, and they looked for three days, but could not find Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came back, Elisha was staying in Jericho. He said to them, “Didn’t I tell you, ‘Don’t go’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of the city said to Elisha, “Look, the city has a good location, as our master can see. But the water is bad and the land doesn’t produce crops.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “Get me a new jar and put some salt in it.” So they got it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went out to the spring and threw the salt in. Then he said, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘I have purified this water. It will no longer cause death or fail to produce crops.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The water has been pure to this very day, just as Elisha prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up from there to Bethel. As he was traveling up the road, some young boys came out of the city and made fun of him, saying, “Go on up, baldy! Go on up, baldy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he turned around and saw them, he called God’s judgment down on them. Two female bears came out of the woods and ripped forty-two of the boys to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he traveled to Mount Carmel and then back to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of King Jehoshaphat’s reign over Judah, Ahab’s son Jehoram became king over Israel in Samaria; he ruled for twelve years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, but not to the same degree as his father and mother. He did remove the sacred pillar of Baal that his father had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet he persisted in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who encouraged Israel to sin; he did not turn from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Mesha of Moab was a sheep breeder. He would send as tribute to the king of Israel 100,000 male lambs and the wool of 100,000 rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time King Jehoram left Samaria and assembled all Israel for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you fight with me against Moab?” Jehoshaphat replied, “I will join you in the campaign; my army and horses are at your disposal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He then asked, “Which invasion route are we going to take?” Jehoram answered, “By the road through the wilderness of Edom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom set out together. They wandered around on the road for seven days and finally ran out of water for the men and animals they had with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said, “Oh no! Certainly the Lord has summoned these three kings so that he can hand them over to the king of Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat asked, “Is there no prophet of the Lord here that we might seek the Lord’s direction?” One of the servants of the king of Israel answered, “Elisha son of Shapat is here; he used to be Elijah’s servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat said, “Yes, he receives the Lord’s messages.” So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat and the king of Edom went down to visit him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to the king of Israel, “Why are you here? Go to your father’s prophets or your mother’s prophets!” The king of Israel replied to him, “No, for the Lord is the one who summoned these three kings so that he can hand them over to Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “As certainly as the Lord of Heaven’s Armies lives (whom I serve), if I did not respect King Jehoshaphat of Judah, I would not pay attention to you or acknowledge you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, get me a musician.” When the musician played, the Lord energized him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘Make many cisterns in this valley,’
speaker: Narrator

text: for this is what the Lord has said, ‘You will not feel any wind or see any rain, but this valley will be full of water, and you and your cattle and animals will drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is an easy task for the Lord; he will also hand Moab over to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will defeat every fortified city and every important city. You must chop down every productive tree, stop up all the springs, and cover all the cultivated land with stones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sure enough, the next morning, at the time of the morning sacrifice, water came flowing down from Edom and filled the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all Moab had heard that the kings were attacking, so everyone old enough to fight was mustered and placed at the border.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they got up early the next morning, the sun was shining on the water. To the Moabites, who were some distance away, the water looked red like blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Moabites said, “It’s blood! The kings must have fought one another! The soldiers have struck one another down! Now, Moab, seize the plunder!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they approached the Israelite camp, the Israelites rose up and struck down the Moabites, who then ran from them. The Israelites thoroughly defeated Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They tore down the cities, and each man threw a stone into every cultivated field until they were covered. They stopped up every spring and chopped down every productive tree.
Only Kir Hareseth was left intact, but the soldiers armed with slings surrounded it and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Moab realized he was losing the battle, he and 700 swordsmen tried to break through and attack the king of Edom, but they failed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took his firstborn son, who was to succeed him as king, and offered him up as a burnt sacrifice on the wall. There was an outburst of divine anger against Israel, so they broke off the attack and returned to their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a wife of one of the prophets appealed to Elisha for help, saying, “Your servant, my husband is dead. You know that your servant was a loyal follower of the Lord. Now the creditor is coming to take away my two boys to be his servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to her, “What can I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in the house?” She answered, “Your servant has nothing in the house except a small jar of olive oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Go and ask all your neighbors for empty containers. Get as many as you can.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and close the door behind you and your sons. Pour the olive oil into all the containers; set aside each one when you have filled it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she left him and closed the door behind her and her sons. As they were bringing the containers to her, she was pouring the olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the containers were full, she said to one of her sons, “Bring me another container.” But he answered her, “There are no more.” Then the olive oil stopped flowing.
speaker: Narrator

text: She went and told the prophet. He said, “Go, sell the olive oil. Repay your creditor, and then you and your sons can live off the rest of the profit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha traveled to Shunem, where a prominent woman lived. She insisted that he stop for a meal. So whenever he was passing through, he would stop in there for a meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her husband, “Look, I’m sure that the man who regularly passes through here is a very special prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s make a small, private upper room and furnish it with a bed, table, chair, and lamp. When he visits us, he can stay there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha came for a visit; he went into the upper room and rested.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told his servant Gehazi, “Ask the Shunammite woman to come here.” So he did so and she came to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to Gehazi, “Tell her, ‘Look, you have treated us with such great respect. What can I do for you? Can I put in a good word for you with the king or the commander of the army?’” She replied, “I’m quite secure.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he asked Gehazi, “What can I do for her?” Gehazi replied, “She has no son, and her husband is old.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told him, “Ask her to come here.” So he did so and she came and stood in the doorway.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “About this time next year you will be holding a son.” She said, “No, my master! O prophet, do not lie to your servant!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman did conceive, and at the specified time the next year she gave birth to a son, just as Elisha had told her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boy grew and one day he went out to see his father who was with the harvest workers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his father, “My head! My head!” His father told a servant, “Carry him to his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he picked him up and took him to his mother. He sat on her lap until noon and then died.
speaker: Narrator

text: She went up and laid him down on the prophet’s bed. She shut the door behind her and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: She called to her husband, “Send me one of the servants and one of the donkeys, so I can go see the prophet quickly and then return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Why do you want to go see him today? It is not the new moon or the Sabbath.” She said, “Everything’s fine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She saddled the donkey and told her servant, “Lead on. Do not stop unless I say so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she went to visit the prophet at Mount Carmel. When he saw her at a distance, he said to his servant Gehazi, “Look, it’s the Shunammite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, run to meet her and ask her, ‘Are you well? Are your husband and the boy well?’” She told Gehazi, “Everything’s fine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when she reached the prophet on the mountain, she grabbed hold of his feet. Gehazi came near to push her away, but the prophet said, “Leave her alone, for she is very upset. The Lord has kept the matter hidden from me; he didn’t tell me about it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Did I ask my master for a son? Didn’t I say, ‘Don’t mislead me?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told Gehazi, “Tuck your robes into your belt, take my staff, and go! Don’t stop to exchange greetings with anyone! Place my staff on the child’s face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The mother of the child said, “As certainly as the Lord lives and as you live, I will not leave you.” So Elisha got up and followed her back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Gehazi went on ahead of them. He placed the staff on the child’s face, but there was no sound or response. When he came back to Elisha he told him, “The child did not wake up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha arrived at the house, there was the child lying dead on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went in by himself and closed the door. Then he prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He got up on the bed and spread his body out over the boy; he put his mouth on the boy’s mouth, his eyes over the boy’s eyes, and the palms of his hands against the boy’s palms. As he bent down across him, the boy’s skin grew warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha went back and walked around in the house. Then he got up on the bed again and bent down over him. The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha called to Gehazi and said, “Get the Shunammite woman.” So he did so and she came to him. He said to her, “Take your son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She came in, fell at his feet, and bowed down. Then she picked up her son and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha went back to Gilgal, while there was a famine in the land. Some of the prophets were visiting him and he told his servant, “Put the big pot on the fire and boil some stew for the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone went out to the field to gather some herbs and found a wild vine. He picked some of its fruit, enough to fill up the fold of his robe. He came back, cut it up, and threw the slices into the stew pot, not knowing they were harmful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stew was poured out for the men to eat. When they ate some of the stew, they cried out, “Death is in the pot, O prophet!” They could not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Get some flour.” Then he threw it into the pot and said, “Now pour some out for the men so they may eat.” There was no longer anything harmful in the pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man from Baal Shalisha brought some food for the prophet—twenty loaves of bread made from the firstfruits of the barley harvest, as well as fresh ears of grain. Elisha said, “Set it before the people so they may eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his attendant said, “How can I feed a hundred men with this?” He replied, “Set it before the people so they may eat, for this is what the Lord has said, ‘They will eat and have some left over.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he set it before them; they ate and had some left over, just as in the Lord’s message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Naaman, the commander of the king of Syria’s army, was esteemed and respected by his master, for through him the Lord had given Syria military victories. But this great warrior had a skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raiding parties went out from Syria and took captive from the land of Israel a young girl, who became a servant to Naaman’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: She told her mistress, “If only my master were in the presence of the prophet who is in Samaria! Then he would cure him of his skin disease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman went and told his master what the girl from the land of Israel had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Syria said, “Go! I will send a letter to the king of Israel.” So Naaman went, taking with him 10 talents of silver, 6,000 shekels of gold, and 10 suits of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the letter to the king of Israel. It read: “This is a letter of introduction for my servant Naaman, whom I have sent to be cured of his skin disease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes and said, “Am I God? Can I kill or restore life? Why does he ask me to cure a man of his skin disease? Certainly you must see that he is looking for an excuse to fight me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha the prophet heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent this message to the king, “Why did you tear your clothes? Send him to me so he may know there is a prophet in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman came with his horses and chariots and stood in the doorway of Elisha’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha sent out a messenger who told him, “Go and wash seven times in the Jordan; your skin will be restored and you will be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman went away angry. He said, “Look, I thought for sure he would come out, stand there, invoke the name of the Lord his God, wave his hand over the area, and cure the skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rivers of Damascus, the Abana and Pharpar, are better than any of the waters of Israel! Could I not wash in them and be healed?” So he turned around and went away angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants approached and said to him, “O master, if the prophet had told you to do some difficult task, you would have been willing to do it. It seems you should be happy that he simply said, ‘Wash and you will be healed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went down and dipped in the Jordan seven times, as the prophet had instructed. His skin became as smooth as a young child’s and he was healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his entire entourage returned to the prophet. Naaman came and stood before him. He said, “For sure I know that there is no God in all the earth except in Israel! Now, please accept a gift from your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha replied, “As certainly as the Lord lives (whom I serve), I will take nothing from you.” Naaman insisted that he take it, but he refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman said, “If not, then please give your servant a load of dirt, enough for a pair of mules to carry, for your servant will never again offer a burnt offering or sacrifice to a god other than the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord forgive your servant for this one thing: When my master enters the temple of Rimmon to worship, and he leans on my arm and I bow down in the temple of Rimmon, may the Lord forgive your servant for this.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha said to him, “Go in peace.”
When he had gone a short distance,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi, the prophet Elisha’s servant, thought, “Look, my master did not accept what this Syrian Naaman offered him. As certainly as the Lord lives, I will run after him and accept something from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gehazi ran after Naaman. When Naaman saw someone running after him, he got down from his chariot to meet him and asked, “Is everything all right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Everything is fine. My master sent me with this message, ‘Look, two servants of the prophets just arrived from the Ephraimite hill country. Please give them a talent of silver and two suits of clothes.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman said, “Please accept two talents of silver.” He insisted, and tied up two talents of silver in two bags, along with two suits of clothes. He gave them to two of his servants and they carried them for Gehazi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived at the hill, he took them from the servants and put them in the house. Then he sent the men on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came and stood before his master, Elisha asked him, “Where have you been, Gehazi?” He answered, “Your servant hasn’t been anywhere.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha replied, “I was there in spirit when a man turned and got down from his chariot to meet you. This is not the proper time to accept silver or to accept clothes, olive groves, vineyards, sheep, cattle, and male and female servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Naaman’s skin disease will afflict you and your descendants forever!” When Gehazi went out from his presence, his skin was as white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the prophets said to Elisha, “Look, the place where we meet with you is too cramped for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s go to the Jordan. Each of us will get a log from there, and we will build a meeting place for ourselves there.” He said, “Go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them said, “Please come along with your servants.” He replied, “All right, I’ll come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they started cutting down trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: As one of them was felling a tree, the ax head dropped into the water. He shouted, “Oh no, my master! It was borrowed!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet asked, “Where did it drop in?” When he showed him the spot, Elisha cut off a branch, threw it in at that spot, and made the ax head float.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Lift it out.” So he reached out his hand and grabbed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Syria was at war with Israel. He consulted his advisers, who said, “Invade at such and such a place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the prophet sent this message to the king of Israel, “Make sure you don’t pass through this place because Syria is invading there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel sent a message to the place the prophet had pointed out, warning it to be on its guard. This happened on several occasions.
speaker: Narrator

text: This made the king of Syria upset. So he summoned his advisers and said to them, “One of us must be helping the king of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his advisers said, “No, my master, O king. The prophet Elisha who lives in Israel keeps telling the king of Israel the things you say in your bedroom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king ordered, “Go, find out where he is, so I can send some men to capture him.” The king was told, “He is in Dothan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent horses and chariots there, along with a good-sized army. They arrived during the night and surrounded the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet’s attendant got up early in the morning. When he went outside there was an army surrounding the city, along with horses and chariots. He said to Elisha, “Oh no, my master! What will we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Don’t be afraid, for our side outnumbers them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha prayed, “O Lord, open his eyes so he can see.” The Lord opened the servant’s eyes, and he saw that the hill was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the army approached him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, “Strike these people with blindness.” The Lord struck them with blindness as Elisha requested.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to them, “This is not the right road or city. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you’re looking for.” He led them to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had entered Samaria, Elisha said, “O Lord, open their eyes, so they can see.” The Lord opened their eyes, and they saw that they were in the middle of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel saw them, he asked Elisha, “Should I strike them down, my master?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Do not strike them down! You did not capture them with your sword or bow, so what gives you the right to strike them down? Give them some food and water, so they can eat and drink and then go back to their master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he threw a big banquet for them and they ate and drank. Then he sent them back to their master. After that no Syrian raiding parties again invaded the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later King Ben Hadad of Syria assembled his entire army and attacked and besieged Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samaria’s food supply ran out. They laid siege to it so long that a donkey’s head was selling for eighty shekels of silver and a quarter of a kab of dove’s droppings for five shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the king of Israel was passing by on the city wall, a woman shouted to him, “Help us, my master, O king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “No, let the Lord help you. How can I help you? The threshing floor and winepress are empty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king asked her, “What’s your problem?” She answered, “This woman said to me, ‘Hand over your son; we’ll eat him today and then eat my son tomorrow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we boiled my son and ate him. Then I said to her the next day, ‘Hand over your son and we’ll eat him.’ But she hid her son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard what the woman said, he tore his clothes. As he was passing by on the wall, the people could see he was wearing sackcloth under his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “May God judge me severely if Elisha son of Shaphat still has his head by the end of the day!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha was sitting in his house with the community leaders. The king sent a messenger on ahead, but before he arrived, Elisha said to the leaders, “Do you realize this assassin intends to cut off my head? Look, when the messenger arrives, shut the door and lean against it. His master will certainly be right behind him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He was still talking to them when the messenger approached and said, “Look, the Lord is responsible for this disaster! Why should I continue to wait for the Lord to help?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha replied, “Listen to the Lord’s message. This is what the Lord has said, ‘About this time tomorrow a seah of finely milled flour will sell for a shekel and two seahs of barley for a shekel at the gate of Samaria.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: An officer who was the king’s right-hand man responded to the prophet, “Look, even if the Lord made it rain by opening holes in the sky, could this happen so soon?” Elisha said, “Look, you will see it happen with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of the food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now four men with a skin disease were sitting at the entrance of the city gate. They said to one another, “Why are we just sitting here waiting to die?
speaker: Narrator

text: If we go into the city, we’ll die of starvation, and if we stay here we’ll die! So come on, let’s defect to the Syrian camp! If they spare us, we’ll live; if they kill us—well, we were going to die anyway.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they started toward the Syrian camp at dusk. When they reached the edge of the Syrian camp, there was no one there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had caused the Syrian camp to hear the sound of chariots and horses and a large army. Then they said to one another, “Look, the king of Israel has paid the kings of the Hittites and Egyptians to attack us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up and fled at dusk, leaving behind their tents, horses, and donkeys. They left the camp as it was and ran for their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men with a skin disease reached the edge of the camp, they entered a tent and had a meal. They also took some silver, gold, and clothes and went and hid it all. Then they went back and entered another tent. They looted it and went and hid what they had taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to one another, “It’s not right what we’re doing! This is a day to celebrate, but we haven’t told anyone. If we wait until dawn, we’ll be punished. So come on, let’s go and inform the royal palace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and called out to the gatekeepers of the city. They told them, “We entered the Syrian camp and there was no one there. We didn’t even hear a man’s voice. But the horses and donkeys are still tied up, and the tents remain up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers relayed the news to the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king got up in the night and said to his advisers, “I will tell you what the Syrians have done to us. They know we are starving, so they left the camp and hid in the field, thinking, ‘When they come out of the city, we will capture them alive and enter the city.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his advisers replied, “Pick some men and have them take five of the horses that are left in the city. (Even if they are killed, their fate will be no different than that of all the Israelite people—we’re all going to die!) Let’s send them out so we can know for sure what’s going on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they picked two horsemen and the king sent them out to track the Syrian army. He ordered them, “Go and find out what’s going on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they tracked them as far as the Jordan. The road was filled with clothes and equipment that the Syrians had discarded in their haste. The scouts went back and told the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people went out and looted the Syrian camp. A seah of finely milled flour sold for a shekel, and two seahs of barley for a shekel, just as in the Lord’s message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king had placed the officer who was his right-hand man at the city gate. When the people rushed out, they trampled him to death in the gate. This fulfilled the prophet’s word which he had spoken when the king tried to arrest him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet had told the king, “Two seahs of barley will sell for a shekel, and a seah of finely milled flour for a shekel; this will happen about this time tomorrow in the gate of Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the officer had replied to the prophet, “Look, even if the Lord made it rain by opening holes in the sky, could this happen so soon?” Elisha had said, “Look, you will see it happen with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of the food!”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is exactly what happened to him. The people trampled him to death in the city gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha advised the woman whose son he had brought back to life, “You and your family should go and live somewhere else for a while, for the Lord has decreed that a famine will overtake the land for seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman did as the prophet said. She and her family went and lived in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seven years the woman returned from the land of the Philistines and went to ask the king to give her back her house and field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king was talking to Gehazi, the prophet’s servant, and said, “Tell me all the great things that Elisha has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Gehazi was telling the king how Elisha had brought the dead back to life, the woman whose son he had brought back to life came to ask the king for her house and field. Gehazi said, “My master, O king, this is the very woman, and this is her son whom Elisha brought back to life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king asked the woman about it, and she gave him the details. The king assigned a eunuch to take care of her request and ordered him, “Give her back everything she owns, as well as the amount of crops her field produced from the day she left the land until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha traveled to Damascus while King Ben Hadad of Syria was sick. The king was told, “The prophet has come here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king told Hazael, “Take a gift and go visit the prophet. Request from him an oracle from the Lord. Ask him, ‘Will I recover from this sickness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hazael went to visit Elisha. He took along a gift, as well as forty camel-loads of all the fine things of Damascus. When he arrived, he stood before him and said, “Your son, King Ben Hadad of Syria, has sent me to you with this question, ‘Will I recover from this sickness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said to him, “Go and tell him, ‘You will surely recover,’ but the Lord has revealed to me that he will surely die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha just stared at him until Hazael became uncomfortable. Then the prophet started crying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazael asked, “Why are you crying, my master?” He replied, “Because I know the trouble you will cause the Israelites. You will set fire to their fortresses, kill their young men with the sword, smash their children to bits, and rip open their pregnant women.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazael said, “How could your servant, who is as insignificant as a dog, accomplish this great military victory?” Elisha answered, “The Lord has revealed to me that you will be the king of Syria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He left Elisha and went to his master. Ben Hadad asked him, “What did Elisha tell you?” Hazael replied, “He told me you would surely recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Hazael took a piece of cloth, dipped it in water, and spread it over Ben Hadad’s face until he died. Then Hazael replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year of the reign of Israel’s King Joram, son of Ahab, Jehoshaphat’s son Jehoram became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was thirty-two years old when he became king and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in the footsteps of the kings of Israel, just as Ahab’s dynasty had done, for he married Ahab’s daughter. He did evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was unwilling to destroy Judah. He preserved Judah for the sake of his servant David to whom he had promised a perpetual dynasty.
speaker: Narrator

text: During his reign Edom freed themselves from Judah’s control and set up their own king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram crossed over to Zair with all his chariots. The Edomites, who had surrounded him, attacked at night and defeated him and his chariot officers. The Israelite army retreated to their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom has remained free from Judah’s control to this very day. At that same time Libnah also rebelled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehoram’s reign, including a record of his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Ahaziah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of the reign of Israel’s King Joram, son of Ahab, Jehoram’s son Ahaziah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, the granddaughter of King Omri of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in the footsteps of Ahab’s dynasty and did evil in the sight of the Lord, as Ahab’s dynasty had done, for he was related to Ahab’s family.
speaker: Narrator

text: He joined Ahab’s son Joram in a battle against King Hazael of Syria at Ramoth Gilead in which the Syrians defeated Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Joram returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he received from the Syrians in Ramah when he fought against King Hazael of Syria. King Ahaziah son of Jehoram of Judah went down to visit Joram son of Ahab in Jezreel, for he was ill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha the prophet summoned a member of the prophetic guild and told him, “Tuck your robes into your belt, take this container of olive oil in your hand, and go to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you arrive there, look for Jehu son of Jehoshaphat son of Nimshi and take him aside into an inner room.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the container of olive oil, pour it over his head, and say, ‘This is what the Lord has said, “I have designated you as king over Israel.”’ Then open the door and run away quickly!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young prophet went to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived, the officers of the army were sitting there. So he said, “I have a message for you, O officer.” Jehu asked, “For which one of us?” He replied, “For you, O officer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu got up and went inside. Then the prophet poured the olive oil on his head and said to him, “This is what the Lord God of Israel has said, ‘I have designated you as king over the Lord’s people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will destroy the family of your master Ahab. I will get revenge against Jezebel for the shed blood of my servants the prophets and for the shed blood of all the Lord’s servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab’s entire family will die. I will cut off every last male belonging to Ahab in Israel, including even the weak and incapacitated.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make Ahab’s dynasty like those of Jeroboam son of Nebat and Baasha son of Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will devour Jezebel on the plot of ground in Jezreel; she will not be buried.’” Then he opened the door and ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu rejoined his master’s servants, they asked him, “Is everything all right? Why did this madman visit you?” He replied, “Ah, it’s not important. You know what kind of man he is and the kinds of things he says.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “You’re lying! Tell us what he said.” So he told them what he had said. He also related how he had said, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘I have designated you as king over Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of them quickly took off his cloak, and they spread them out at Jehu’s feet on the steps. The trumpet was blown and they shouted, “Jehu is king!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehu son of Jehoshaphat son of Nimshi conspired against Joram.
Now Joram had been in Ramoth Gilead with the whole Israelite army, guarding against an invasion by King Hazael of Syria.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Joram had returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he received from the Syrians when he fought against King Hazael of Syria. Jehu told his supporters, “If you really want me to be king, then don’t let anyone escape from the city to go and warn Jezreel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu drove his chariot to Jezreel, for Joram was recuperating there. (Now King Ahaziah of Judah had come down to visit Joram.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the watchman was standing on the tower in Jezreel and saw Jehu’s troops approaching. He said, “I see troops!” Joram ordered, “Send a rider out to meet them and have him ask, ‘Is everything all right?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the horseman went to meet him and said, “This is what the king says, ‘Is everything all right?’” Jehu replied, “None of your business! Follow me.” The watchman reported, “The messenger reached them, but hasn’t started back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent a second horseman out to them and he said, “This is what the king says, ‘Is everything all right?’” Jehu replied, “None of your business! Follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman reported, “He reached them, but hasn’t started back. The one who drives the lead chariot drives like Jehu son of Nimshi; he drives recklessly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram ordered, “Hitch up my chariot.” When his chariot had been hitched up, King Joram of Israel and King Ahaziah of Judah went out in their respective chariots to meet Jehu. They met up with him in the plot of land that had once belonged to Naboth of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joram saw Jehu, he asked, “Is everything all right, Jehu?” He replied, “How can everything be all right as long as your mother Jezebel promotes idolatry and pagan practices?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram turned his chariot around and took off. He said to Ahaziah, “It’s a trap, Ahaziah!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu aimed his bow and shot an arrow right between Joram’s shoulders. The arrow went through his heart and he fell to his knees in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu ordered his officer Bidkar, “Pick him up and throw him into the part of the field that once belonged to Naboth of Jezreel. Remember, you and I were riding together behind his father, Ahab, when the Lord pronounced this oracle against him,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘“Know for sure that I saw the shed blood of Naboth and his sons yesterday,” says the Lord, “and that I will give you what you deserve right here in this plot of land,” says the Lord.’ So now pick him up and throw him into this plot of land, just as in the Lord’s message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Ahaziah of Judah saw what happened, he took off up the road to Beth Haggan. Jehu chased him and ordered, “Shoot him too.” They shot him while he was driving his chariot up the ascent of Gur near Ibleam. He fled to Megiddo and died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants took his body back to Jerusalem and buried him in his tomb with his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah had become king over Judah in the eleventh year of Joram son of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu approached Jezreel. When Jezebel heard the news, she put on some eye liner, fixed up her hair, and leaned out the window.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu came through the gate, she said, “Is everything all right, Zimri, murderer of his master?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up at the window and said, “Who is on my side? Who?” Two or three eunuchs looked down at him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Throw her down!” So they threw her down, and when she hit the ground, her blood splattered against the wall and the horses, and Jehu drove his chariot over her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went inside and had a meal. Then he said, “Dispose of this accursed woman’s corpse. Bury her, for after all, she was a king’s daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they went to bury her, they found nothing left but the skull, feet, and palms of the hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went back and told him. Then he said, “It is the fulfillment of the Lord’s message that he had spoken through his servant, Elijah the Tishbite, ‘In the plot of land at Jezreel, dogs will devour Jezebel’s flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezebel’s corpse will be like manure on the surface of the ground in the plot of land at Jezreel. People will not be able to even recognize her.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab had seventy sons living in Samaria. So Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria to the leading officials of Jezreel and to the guardians of Ahab’s dynasty. This is what the letters said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have with you the sons of your master, chariots and horses, a fortified city, and weapons. So when this letter arrives,
speaker: Narrator

text: pick the best and most capable of your master’s sons, place him on his father’s throne, and defend your master’s dynasty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were absolutely terrified and said, “Look, two kings could not stop him! How can we?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the palace supervisor, the city commissioner, the leaders, and the guardians sent this message to Jehu, “We are your subjects! Whatever you say, we will do. We will not make anyone king. Do what you consider proper.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He wrote them a second letter, saying, “If you are really on my side and are willing to obey me, then take the heads of your master’s sons and come to me in Jezreel at this time tomorrow.” Now the king had seventy sons, and the prominent men of the city were raising them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they received the letter, they seized the king’s sons and executed all seventy of them. They put their heads in baskets and sent them to him in Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger came and told Jehu, “They have brought the heads of the king’s sons.” Jehu said, “Stack them in two piles at the entrance of the city gate until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning he went out and stood there. Then he said to all the people, “You are innocent. I conspired against my master and killed him. But who struck down all of these men?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore take note that not one of the Lord’s words which he pronounced against Ahab’s dynasty will fail to materialize. The Lord has done what he announced through his servant Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu killed all who were left of Ahab’s family in Jezreel, and all his nobles, close friends, and priests. He left no survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu then left there and set out for Samaria. While he was traveling through Beth Eked of the Shepherds,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu encountered the relatives of King Ahaziah of Judah. He asked, “Who are you?” They replied, “We are Ahaziah’s relatives. We have come down to see how the king’s sons and the queen mother’s sons are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Capture them alive!” So they captured them alive and then executed all forty-two of them by the cistern at Beth Eked. He left no survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he left there, he met Jehonadab son of Rekab who had been looking for him. Jehu greeted him and asked, “Are you as committed to me as I am to you?” Jehonadab answered, “I am!” Jehu replied, “If so, give me your hand.” So he offered his hand and Jehu pulled him up into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu said, “Come with me and see how zealous I am for the Lord’s cause.” So he took him along in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to Samaria and killed each of Ahab’s remaining family members who were in Samaria until he destroyed them, in keeping with the Lord’s message which he had announced to Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu assembled all the people and said to them, “Ahab worshiped Baal a little; Jehu will worship him with great devotion.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, bring to me all the prophets of Baal, as well as all his servants and priests. None of them must be absent, for I am offering a great sacrifice to Baal. Any of them who fails to appear will lose his life.” But Jehu was tricking them so he could destroy the servants of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu ordered, “Make arrangements for a celebration for Baal.” So they announced it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu sent invitations throughout Israel, and all the servants of Baal came; not one was absent. They arrived at the temple of Baal and filled it up from end to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu ordered the one who was in charge of the wardrobe, “Bring out robes for all the servants of Baal.” So he brought out robes for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu and Jehonadab son of Rekab went to the temple of Baal. Jehu said to the servants of Baal, “Make sure there are no servants of the Lord here with you; there must be only servants of Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went inside to offer sacrifices and burnt offerings. Now Jehu had stationed eighty men outside. He had told them, “If any of the men inside gets away, you will pay with your lives!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he finished offering the burnt sacrifice, Jehu ordered the royal guard and officers, “Come in and strike them down! Don’t let any escape!” So the royal guard and officers struck them down with the sword and left their bodies lying there. Then they entered the inner sanctuary of the temple of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hauled out the sacred pillar of the temple of Baal and burned it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They demolished the sacred pillar of Baal and the temple of Baal; it is used as a latrine to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu eradicated Baal worship from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Jehu did not repudiate the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had encouraged Israel to commit; the golden calves remained in Bethel and Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Jehu, “You have done well. You have accomplished my will and carried out my wishes with regard to Ahab’s dynasty. Therefore four generations of your descendants will rule over Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu did not carefully and wholeheartedly obey the law of the Lord God of Israel. He did not repudiate the sins which Jeroboam had encouraged Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Lord began to reduce the size of Israel’s territory. Hazael attacked their eastern border.
speaker: Narrator

text: He conquered all the land of Gilead, including the territory of Gad, Reuben, and Manasseh, extending all the way from the Aroer in the Arnon Valley through Gilead to Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehu’s reign, including all his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu passed away and was buried in Samaria. His son Jehoahaz replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu reigned over Israel for twenty-eight years in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, saw that her son was dead, she was determined to destroy the entire royal line.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram and sister of Ahaziah, took Ahaziah’s son Joash and stole him away from the rest of the royal descendants who were to be executed. She hid him and his nurse in the room where the bed covers were stored. So he was hidden from Athaliah and escaped execution.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hid out with his nurse in the Lord’s temple for six years, while Athaliah was ruling over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year Jehoiada summoned the officers of the units of hundreds of the Carians and the royal bodyguard. He met with them in the Lord’s temple. He made an agreement with them and made them swear an oath of allegiance in the Lord’s temple. Then he showed them the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered them, “This is what you must do. One third of the unit that is on duty during the Sabbath will guard the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another third of you will be stationed at the Foundation Gate. Still another third of you will be stationed at the gate behind the royal guard. You will take turns guarding the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two units who are off duty on the Sabbath will guard the Lord’s temple and protect the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must surround the king. Each of you must hold his weapon in his hand. Whoever approaches your ranks must be killed. You must accompany the king wherever he goes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officers of the units of hundreds did just as Jehoiada the priest ordered. Each of them took his men, those who were on duty during the Sabbath as well as those who were off duty on the Sabbath, and reported to Jehoiada the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest gave to the officers of the units of hundreds King David’s spears and the shields that were kept in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The royal bodyguard took their stations, each holding his weapon in his hand. They lined up from the south side of the temple to the north side and stood near the altar and the temple, surrounding the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada led out the king’s son and placed on him the crown and the royal insignia. They proclaimed him king and poured olive oil on his head. They clapped their hands and cried out, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah heard the royal guard shout, she joined the crowd at the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she saw the king standing by the pillar, according to custom. The officers stood beside the king with their trumpets, and all the people of the land were celebrating and blowing trumpets. Athaliah tore her clothes and screamed, “Treason, treason!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada the priest ordered the officers of the units of hundreds, who were in charge of the army, “Bring her outside the temple to the guards. Put to death by the sword anyone who follows her.” The priest gave this order because he had decided she should not be executed in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They seized her and took her into the precincts of the royal palace through the horses’ entrance. There she was executed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada then drew up a covenant between the Lord and the king and people, stipulating that they should be loyal to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of the land went and demolished the temple of Baal. They smashed its altars and idols to bits. They killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altar. Jehoiada the priest then placed guards at the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the officers of the units of hundreds, the Carians, the royal bodyguard, and all the people of the land, and together they led the king down from the Lord’s temple. They entered the royal palace through the Gate of the Royal Bodyguard, and the king sat down on the royal throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of the land celebrated, for the city had rest now that they had killed Athaliah with the sword in the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: (12:1) Jehoash was seven years old when he began to reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: (12:2) In Jehu’s seventh year Jehoash became king; he reigned for forty years in Jerusalem. His mother was Zibiah, who was from Beer Sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash did what the Lord approved all his days when Jehoiada the priest taught him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash said to the priests, “I place at your disposal all the consecrated silver that has been brought to the Lord’s temple, including the silver collected from the census tax, the silver received from those who have made vows, and all the silver that people have voluntarily contributed to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests should receive the silver they need from the treasurers and repair any damage to the temple they discover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: By the twenty-third year of King Jehoash’s reign the priests had still not repaired the damage to the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoash summoned Jehoiada the priest along with the other priests, and said to them, “Why have you not repaired the damage to the temple? Now, take no more silver from your treasurers unless you intend to use it to repair the damage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests agreed not to collect silver from the people and relieved themselves of personal responsibility for the temple repairs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada the priest took a chest and drilled a hole in its lid. He placed it on the right side of the altar near the entrance of the Lord’s temple. The priests who guarded the entrance would put into it all the silver brought to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw the chest was full of silver, the royal secretary and the high priest counted the silver that had been brought to the Lord’s temple and bagged it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would then hand over the silver that had been weighed to the construction foremen assigned to the Lord’s temple. They hired carpenters and builders to work on the Lord’s temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as masons and stonecutters. They bought wood and chiseled stone to repair the damage to the Lord’s temple and also paid for all the other expenses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The silver brought to the Lord’s temple was not used for silver bowls, trimming shears, basins, trumpets, or any kind of gold or silver implements.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was handed over to the foremen who used it to repair the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not audit the treasurers who disbursed the funds to the foremen, for they were honest.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The silver collected in conjunction with reparation offerings and sin offerings was not brought to the Lord’s temple; it belonged to the priests.)
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time King Hazael of Syria attacked Gath and captured it. Hazael then decided to attack Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoash of Judah collected all the sacred items that his ancestors Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, kings of Judah, had consecrated, as well as his own sacred items and all the gold that could be found in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and the royal palace. He sent it all to King Hazael of Syria, who then withdrew from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Joash’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants conspired against him and murdered Joash at Beth Millo, on the road that goes down to Silla.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants Jozabad son of Shimeath and Jehozabad son of Shomer murdered him. He was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Amaziah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-third year of the reign of Judah’s King Joash son of Ahaziah, Jehu’s son Jehoahaz became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for seventeen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He continued in the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who had encouraged Israel to sin; he did not repudiate those sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was furious with Israel and handed them over to King Hazael of Syria and to Hazael’s son Ben Hadad for many years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz asked for the Lord’s mercy, and the Lord responded favorably, for he saw that Israel was oppressed by the king of Syria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord provided a deliverer for Israel, and they were freed from Syria’s power. The Israelites once more lived in security.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not repudiate the sinful ways of the family of Jeroboam, who encouraged Israel to sin; they continued in those sins. There was even an Asherah pole standing in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz had no army left except for 50 horsemen, 10 chariots, and 10,000 foot soldiers. The king of Syria had destroyed his troops and trampled on them as dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehoahaz’s reign, including all his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz passed away and was buried in Samaria. His son Jehoash replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of King Jehoash’s reign over Judah, Jehoahaz’s son Jehoash became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for sixteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin; he continued in those sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehoash’s reign, including all his accomplishments and his successful war with King Amaziah of Judah, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash passed away and Jeroboam succeeded him on the throne. Jehoash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elisha had a terminal illness. King Jehoash of Israel went down to visit him. He wept before him and said, “My father, my father! The chariot and horsemen of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told him, “Take a bow and some arrows,” and he did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha told the king of Israel, “Aim the bow.” He did so, and Elisha placed his hands on the king’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “Open the east window,” and he did so. Elisha said, “Shoot!” and he did so. Elisha said, “This arrow symbolizes the victory the Lord will give you over Syria. You will annihilate Syria in Aphek!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said, “Take the arrows,” and he did so. He told the king of Israel, “Strike the ground!” He struck the ground three times and stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet got angry at him and said, “If you had struck the ground five or six times, you would have annihilated Syria! But now, you will defeat Syria only three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha died and was buried. Moabite raiding parties invaded the land at the beginning of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day some men were burying a man when they spotted a raiding party. So they threw the dead man into Elisha’s tomb. When the body touched Elisha’s bones, the dead man came to life and stood on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Hazael of Syria oppressed Israel throughout Jehoahaz’s reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord had mercy on them and felt pity for them. He extended his favor to them because of the promise he had made to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He has been unwilling to destroy them or remove them from his presence to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Hazael of Syria died, his son Ben Hadad replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz’s son Jehoash took back from Ben Hadad son of Hazael the cities that he had taken from his father Jehoahaz in war. Jehoash defeated him three times and recovered the Israelite cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of the reign of Israel’s King Joash son of Joahaz, Joash’s son Amaziah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jehoaddan, who was from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord approved, but not like David his ancestor had done. He followed the example of his father Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had secured control of the kingdom, he executed the servants who had assassinated his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not execute the sons of the assassins. He obeyed the Lord’s commandment as recorded in the scroll of the law of Moses, “Fathers must not be put to death for what their sons do, and sons must not be put to death for what their fathers do. A man must be put to death only for his own sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He defeated 10,000 Edomites in the Salt Valley; he captured Sela in battle and renamed it Joktheel, a name it has retained to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz son of Jehu, king of Israel. He said, “Come, let’s meet face to face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoash of Israel sent this message back to King Amaziah of Judah, “A thornbush in Lebanon sent this message to a cedar in Lebanon, ‘Give your daughter to my son as a wife.’ Then a wild animal of Lebanon came by and trampled down the thorn.
speaker: Narrator

text: You thoroughly defeated Edom, and it has gone to your head! Gloat over your success, but stay in your palace. Why bring calamity on yourself? Why bring down yourself and Judah along with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah would not heed the warning, so King Jehoash of Israel attacked. He and King Amaziah of Judah met face to face in Beth Shemesh of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah was defeated by Israel, and each man ran back home.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoash of Israel captured King Amaziah of Judah, son of Jehoash son of Ahaziah, in Beth Shemesh. He attacked Jerusalem and broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the Gate of Ephraim to the Corner Gate—a distance of about 600 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took away all the gold and silver, all the items found in the Lord’s temple and in the treasuries of the royal palace, and some hostages. Then he went back to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehoash’s reign, including all his accomplishments and his successful war with King Amaziah of Judah, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash passed away and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. His son Jeroboam replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Amaziah son of Joash of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of King Jehoash son of Jehoahaz of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Amaziah’s reign are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Conspirators plotted against him in Jerusalem, so he fled to Lachish. But they sent assassins after him, and they killed him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His body was carried back by horses, and he was buried in Jerusalem with his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in his father Amaziah’s place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah built up Elat and restored it to Judah after the king had passed away.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Judah’s King Amaziah son of Joash, Jeroboam son of Joash became king over Israel. He reigned for forty-one years in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He restored the border of Israel from Lebo Hamath in the north to the sea of the rift valley in the south, just as in the message from the Lord God of Israel that he had announced through his servant Jonah son of Amittai, the prophet from Gath Hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw Israel’s intense suffering; everyone was weak and incapacitated and Israel had no deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had not decreed that he would blot out Israel’s memory from under heaven, so he delivered them through Jeroboam son of Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jeroboam’s reign, including all his accomplishments, his military success in restoring Israelite control over Damascus and Hamath, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam passed away and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. His son Zechariah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year of King Jeroboam’s reign over Israel, Amaziah’s son Azariah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was sixteen years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jecholiah, who was from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord approved, just as his father Amaziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord afflicted the king with an illness; he suffered from a skin disease until the day he died. He lived in separate quarters, while his son Jotham was in charge of the palace and ruled over the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Azariah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Jotham replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-eighth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Jeroboam’s son Zechariah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord, as his ancestors had done. He did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh conspired against him; he assassinated him in Ibleam and took his place as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Zechariah’s reign are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: His assassination fulfilled the Lord’s message to Jehu, “Four generations of your descendants will rule on Israel’s throne.” And that is how it happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of King Uzziah’s reign over Judah. He reigned for one month in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem son of Gadi went up from Tirzah to Samaria and attacked Shallum son of Jabesh. He killed him and took his place as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Shallum’s reign, including the conspiracy he organized, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Menahem came from Tirzah and attacked Tiphsah. He struck down all who lived in the city and the surrounding territory, because they would not surrender. He even ripped open the pregnant women.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-ninth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Menahem son of Gadi became king over Israel. He reigned for ten years in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who encouraged Israel to sin.
During his reign,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pul king of Assyria invaded the land, and Menahem paid him 1,000 talents of silver to gain his support and to solidify his control of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem got this silver by taxing all the wealthy men in Israel; he took fifty shekels of silver from each one of them and paid it to the king of Assyria. Then the king of Assyria left; he did not stay there in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Menahem’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem passed away and his son Pekahiah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fiftieth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Menahem’s son Pekahiah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: His officer Pekah son of Remaliah conspired against him. He and fifty Gileadites assassinated Pekahiah, as well as Argob and Arieh, in Samaria in the fortress of the royal palace. Pekah then took his place as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Pekahiah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifty-second year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Pekah’s reign over Israel, King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria came and captured Ijon, Abel Beth Maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, and Galilee, including all the territory of Naphtali. He deported the people to Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah son of Remaliah. He assassinated him and took his place as king, in the twentieth year of the reign of Jotham son of Uzziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Pekah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year of the reign of Israel’s King Pekah son of Remaliah, Uzziah’s son Jotham became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jerusha the daughter of Zadok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord approved, just as his father Uzziah had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places. He built the Upper Gate to the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jotham’s reign, including his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Lord prompted King Rezin of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah to attack Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of his ancestor David. His son Ahaz replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventeenth year of the reign of Pekah son of Remaliah, Jotham’s son Ahaz became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. He did not do what pleased the Lord his God, in contrast to his ancestor David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in the footsteps of the kings of Israel. He passed his son through the fire, a horrible sin practiced by the nations whom the Lord drove out from before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel attacked Jerusalem. They besieged Ahaz, but were unable to conquer him.
speaker: Narrator

text: (At that time King Rezin of Syria recovered Elat for Syria; he drove the Judahites from there. Syrians arrived in Elat and live there to this very day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz sent messengers to King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria, saying, “I am your servant and your dependent. March up and rescue me from the power of the king of Syria and the king of Israel, who have attacked me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahaz took the silver and gold that were in the Lord’s temple and in the treasuries of the royal palace and sent it as tribute to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria responded favorably to his request; he attacked Damascus and captured it. He deported the people to Kir and executed Rezin.
speaker: Narrator
